instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
Hey Guys, 

Working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with severe water damage and corrosion. Replaced all bad components, using original Apple MagSafe 60w green light but no fan spin. 

Here my measures:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 12.57v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> : 3.398v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> : 0.452v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> : 0.384v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> : 2v (not normal)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> : 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> : 0v

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> : 0v

<SIGNAL>PCH_SUSACK_L</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> : 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> : 2v (not normal)

<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> : 0v

Replaced <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> still 2v
Missing S4 rails also.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If yes, then check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals, at same time.

Did you try SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 61623, member: 682"]
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
[/QUOTE]
Yes, drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> : 3.42v to 0.349v

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 61623, member: 682"]
Did you try SMC bypass mode?
[/QUOTE]
How do i try this ?! 

No pulse for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals, still 0v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
Looks like you have PCH issue.

"How do i try this ?!"
Press power button, connect charger and maintain pressing 5-10s.
Remove battery first.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
Cleaning area around CPU/PCH, now <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulsing from 2.472v to 0v for less than a second.

PCH issue ???

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:

???

Did you check for pulse at all big coils?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 61662, member: 682"]
"Did you try SMC bypass mode?"
[/QUOTE]
Yes, nothing happen. Fan still not spinning.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 61662, member: 682"]
Did you check for pulse at all big coils?
[/QUOTE]
Yes, except for L7310 (12.57v) and L7560 (3.3v) other coils just 0v (not pulsing)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
"now <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulsing from 2.472v to 0v"
When it is high, machine must exit from S5 state, going to S3.
Do you get pulse on other <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signal at same time?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, water damage, green light, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 2v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 61708, member: 682"]
Do you ger pulse on other <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signal at same time?
[/QUOTE]
Yes, due to really bad water damage and corrosion it highly PCH issue.

I'll skip this and working another board right now.
Thanks for your help 2informaticos ?
